title: Should I consider filing bankruptcy for $25k in credit card debt? I have no job and am living off my savings.
question: I've been unemployed for the past 6 years, and married the last 4 years. We accumulated credit card debt, but paid most of it off during the marriage. Now we are separated, I am still paying off $25k in cc debt, I have no income, but I still have $35k in savings. My husband will not settle our divorce unless I agree to give him $50k, which we used to pay down our cc debt incurred during marriage, plus he wants half the equity increase in my home (owned by me and in my name only since before the marriage). My home is all I have besides what's left of my savings which I need to pay for my living expenses. What are my options?
answers: Chapter 7 may be the best option. But you need to engage in some pre-bankruptcy planning to protect the cash you have. Do not make any further payments until you know what your options are.

Consultations are typically free and under these circumstances it would make sense to discuss details with a lawyer. There may be a couple of issues here (asset exemptions, division of assets and debts in divorce). Sometimes it is not a question of whether to file but when. Talk to someone now though so you can better understand how it works and can position yourself appropriately. Keep in mind that ex-spouse can ask for a lot of things but how assets and debts will be divided remains to be seen. I hope your family law attorney is working through those issues.

You have a very typical situation that should be addressed in a bankruptcy. There are San Diego Attorneys that offer free consultations. I suggest you speak with one as soon as possible before all your savings are depleted. You have several options available. Family Law and bankruptcy often cross over each other.

Bankruptcy is not done just because you have a lot of debt. If you file BK now, then the divorce matter will be put on hold until the BK court determines if you qualify for BK, and if you do, then you might be ordered to use your assets to satisfy your debts. From the few facts, I don't see that you would qualify for BK. As to your spouse's demands to pay $50k, it doesn't seem reasonable as it appears the previous debt was a CP debt and it was paid off by CP funds. You haven't stated what the home is worth either so that may also prevent you from going to BK court. Seek legal assistance as to the divorce from a skilled family law attorney as that might provide the pathway to getting out of debt and salvaging some assets for both.

Talk with an experiences bankruptcy attorney right away in order to determine how much of your assets are exempt in bankruptcy and to plan for it. Then talk to an experienced divorce attorney to understand your rights in a divorce under the California community property laws. You need to coordinate the two laws in order to get the best fresh start to you new llfe as a single debt free person.

You sound like a good candidate for Chapter 7 to eliminate your debt since you currently do not have income coming in. Your biggest concerns is going to be protecting the $35k in savings and the equity in your home. Meet with an experienced BK attorney right away to go over your assets and make sure you can protect all of them. If so, it seems like you should go forward with the BK to rid yourself of your liabilities.

A Chapter 7 bankruptcy may erase your credit card debt. However, it is likely that your savings will not be fully exempt. In other words, the trustee could use some of the savings to pay down your debts. Once you file a Chapter 7, you do not have the right to dismiss the case either. Once you file, you could be stuck in the case. You should discuss how to handle this unexempt asset with a bankruptcy attorney in your area.
You need to hire attorney. You don't owe him reimbusement for CP payment if CP deby. He does have a CP claim as to the house.

This is not a family law issue, it is a bankruptcy issue.

Your 35K in your savings account may be a problem. If you file bankruptcy, the trustee may look at that as you having the ability to pay the debt. This is just general information and you need to speak with an bankruptcy attorney who can review the facts and give you a more educated answer.
